In light of the Swell Conference and the Gates Foundation's decision to use Ripple tech for mobile payments, let's discuss Ripple.
Ripple is best known as a digital currency (XRP), but its main value proposition is its payments protocol.
The protocol works with "IOUs" to transmit money without actually moving it. It works by setting up a credit relationship between two parties.
For instance, you might owe your friend across the ocean $100. Instead of wiring him the money, you issue him an "IOU" over the Ripple Network.
This is just as applicable for any asset, from gold to french fries. The whole system works if both parties trust each other's ability to redeem the underlying.
This is perfect for banking, but there's still counterparty risk. What if one party doesn't trust the other's ability to stay solvent, for instance?
Ripple is betting that banks will choose to use XRP instead of IOUs as a "currency of last resort" to bridge across all asset classes. It enables near-instant settlement and lower transaction fees.
Perhaps by design, Ripple is a highly centralized cryptocurrency, with Ripple owning most validator nodes and over 60% of total XRP supply in lockup.
In this way, the organization acts as a reserve bank, controlling XRP issuance and managing the service.
